facts.text: One Mammotty was married to Seinaba.
Mammotty made a gift of his properties including immovable property to Seinaba on April 7, 1944 by a registered deed.
At the time of the gift, Seinaba was 15 years 9 months old (minor).
Gift accepted on behalf of Seinaba by her mother, Katheesumma (first appellant), who took possession.
Mammotty was ill for a long time, in hospital, discharged uncured a month before the gift deed, and remained in his mother-in-law's house afterwards.
Plea that gift was made in contemplation of death and voidable, rejected by trial Judge and first Appellate Judge.
Mammotty died on May 3, 1946 without issue.
Seinaba died on February 25, 1947 without leaving an issue.
Suit brought by Kunhamu, elder brother of Mammotty, for partition and possession of 6/16 share of the property as heir under Muhammadan Law, challenging gift as invalid.
Kunhamu joined his two sisters as defendants, entitled to 3/16 share each.
Defendants 1 to 3 (appellants) are heirs of Seinaba, entitled to remaining 4/16 share.
Kunhamu's contention: On Mammotty's death, widow Seinaba entitled to 1/4 share (no issue), remaining 3/4 divisible: Kunhamu 6/16, sisters 3/16 each; gift invalid so shares unaffected.
Kerala High Court and courts below held gift invalid as not accepted by legal guardian of property (father or grandfather or executor).
Appeal by special leave by defendants Nos. 1 to 3 from Kerala High Court judgment dated June 23, 1960 in Second Appeal No. 103 of 1957.
Mammotty living at time of gift in house of his mother-in-law; minor wife attained discretion, living at mother's house in her care where husband also residing.

legal_issues.text: Is a gift by a husband to his minor wife and accepted on her behalf by her mother valid under Muhammadan Law?

petitioner_arguments.text: Neither express acceptance nor transfer of possession is necessary for completion of a gift, when the donor is himself the guardian or de-facto guardian or quasi-guardian provided there is real and bona fide intention to transfer ownership.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Muhammadan Law principles on gifts to minors

petitioner_arguments.text: No delivery of possession necessary in gift by husband to minor wife if intention manifested; law presumes subsequent holding on behalf of minor wife.
When husband makes gift to minor wife and no legal guardian of property exists, gift completed by delivery to and acceptance by person in whose control minor is; donor can appoint such person.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Analogous principles of Muhammadan Law relating to gifts to minors accepted by persons other than four categories of legal guardians

respondent_arguments.text: Gift invalid unless accepted by legal guardian of property (father, executor, grandfather, executor); mother (Katheesumma) not legal guardian of Seinaba's property.
Mammotty could have taken possession as guardian of minor wife but did not; possession given to mother insufficient.

court_reasoning.text: Gift (Hiba) requires declaration (ijab), acceptance (qabul), delivery of possession (qabza); here declaration and tender by registered deed, possession delivered to mother on behalf of minor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Registered deed manifests clear intention; possession recorded as delivered.

court_reasoning.text: Mother not guardian of property (Wilayat-ul-Mal: father, grandfather, executors); but exceptions exist where no such guardian, especially for gifts to minors in care of mother or others.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Hanafi law allows by analogy (qiyas), istehsan, istislah; texts like Hedaya, Durrul-Mukhtar support possession by mother for orphan/fatherless minor.

court_reasoning.text: Husband can take possession for minor wife post-marriage; but here mother accepted as minor in her charge, no father/grandfather alive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Relaxed rules for husband-wife gifts, minors without guardians; precedents confirm.

court_reasoning.text: Strict possession rules relaxed for father to child, wife to husband, guardians to wards, and where minor in charge of mother/stranger/brother/uncle absent father.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Texts (Hedaya p.484, Baillie, Fatawa-i-Alamgiri) and modern authors (Mulla, Tyabji, Amir Ali) support.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes cases where father alive (Suna Mia, Musa Miya); here no guardian, gift through mother valid for minor's benefit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Judicial Committee (Md. Abdul Ghani, Mohammad Sadiq Ali Khan) emphasizes intention over technicalities in modern context.

court_reasoning.text: Facts show clear intention: registered deed handed to mother-in-law, accepted for minor; Mammotty divested ownership.

holdings.text: Gift by husband to minor wife accepted by mother (no legal property guardian existing) is valid under Muhammadan Law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohammad Sadiq Ali Khan v. Fakhr Jahan
precedents_cited.relevance: Mutation not necessary if deed declares possession delivered to wife; between husband-wife, no actual vacation/possession needed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Md. Abdul Ghani v. Mt. Fakhr Jahan
precedents_cited.relevance: Muhammadan law on gifts considers intention; handing deed suffices as evidence of transfer, not rigid possession rules.
Gift not fail merely without possession to father/guardian; donor can nominate acceptor for minor.
Similar to above on nomination for minor.
Document delivery to minor with discretion = acceptance; overt act shows intention.

precedents_cited.case_name: Suna Mia v. S. A. S. Pillai
precedents_cited.relevance: Gift to minor through mother invalid where father alive.
Gift by grandfather to grandsons invalid without possession to alive father.

statutes_cited.name: Guardian and Wards Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Husband is guardian of person after marriage unless unfit; mother has hizanat till puberty.

outcome.summary: The appeal is allowed; the gift by Mammotty to his minor wife Seinaba, accepted by her mother, held valid under Muhammadan Law. Plaintiff's suit challenging the gift dismissed; properties vest with heirs of Seinaba.

key_quotes.text: Is a gift by a husband to his minor wife and accepted on her behalf by her mother valid?
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core legal question framed by the Court.

key_quotes.text: In our judgment the gift in the present case was a valid gift.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The object of the Mohammedan law as to gifts apparently was to prevent disputes as to whether the donor and the donee intended at the time that the title to the property should pass.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose, citing Judicial Committee; emphasizes intention over technicalities.
